prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a correlator setup that targets CO[1-0] emission for all galaxies at multiple redshifts, with one tuning (as the sources lie within 10 degrees). Since this is a detection experiment and we are not particularly interested in the profile of the lines, we request the second coarsest spectral resolution smoothed to 20-30 km/sec (using spectral averaging of 16), over a total bandwidth per baseband of 1875MHz.

We are interested in measuring the galaxy-scale, integrated CO emission. Therefore, a spatial resolution of 4arcsec, similar to the projected angular size of our sources based on optical imaging, is adequete for the purposes of our proposal. The average redshift of our sample is <z>=0.121

Our sources benifit from detailed near to far-IR broadband data (3.6 to 500um - Spitzer/Herschel) that allow a robust determination of their LIR. Using the LIR-LCO relation of Sargent et al. 2014, we estimate that all our sources have I_CO > 1.2 Jy km/sec. Adopting a FWHM of 300 km/sec for the CO[1-0] line, (typical for such systems, e.g. Magdis et al. 2014), we estimate a flux denisty of S_CO > 4mJy. Therefore to achieve a 5 sigma detection we request an rms of 0.8mJy. Since this is a detection experiment and we are not interested in fitting the line profile, 4 reslotion elements are for the purposes of our prosolal. Therefore a bandwidth sensitivity of 75km/sec (assuming a FWHM of 300km/sec) is adequate for the purposes of this experiment.

We have chosen a correlator setup that targets CO[1-0] emission for all galaxies at multiple redshifts, with one tuning (as the sources lie within 10 degrees). Since this is a detection experiment and we are not particularly interested in the profile of the lines, we request the second coarsest spectral resolution smoothed to 20-30 km/sec (using spectral averaging of 16), over a total bandwidth per baseband of 1875MHz.

We are interested in measuring the galaxy-scale, integrated CO emission. Therefore, a spatial resolution of 4arcsec, similar to the projected angular size of our sources based on optical imaging, is adequete for the purposes of our proposal. The average redshift of our sample is <z>=0.121

Our sources benifit from detailed near to far-IR broadband data (3.6 to 500um - Spitzer/Herschel) that allow a robust determination of their LIR. Using the LIR-LCO relation of Sargent et al. 2014, we estimate that all our sources have I_CO > 1.2 Jy km/sec. Adopting a FWHM of 300 km/sec for the CO[1-0] line, (typical for such systems, e.g. Magdis et al. 2014), we estimate a flux denisty of S_CO > 4mJy. Therefore to achieve a 5 sigma detection we request an rms of 0.8mJy. Since this is a detection experiment and we are not interested in fitting the line profile, 4 reslotion elements are for the purposes of our prosolal. Therefore a bandwidth sensitivity of 75km/sec (assuming a FWHM of 300km/sec) is adequate for the purposes of this experiment.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent studies have tried to establish a link between the warm dust emission of the galaxies, as traced by the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), and the cold gas as traced by CO observations, showing that sources with PAH deficiency are characterised by high star formation efficiencies (SFE) and compact star forming regions. However, these studies are limited to local galaxies and a small number of high-z (z>1) ultra luminous sources. To bridge this gap we propose CO[1-0] observations with ALMA Band 3 for a well studied sample of 22 star forming galaxies at 0.05<z<0.25, that benifit from high quality IRS mid-IR spectroscopy as well as from broadband Spitzer and Herschel data. The aim of this proposal is to bring together local, high-z and intermediate redshift samples of star forming galaxies in order to: 1) study whether there is a universal LCO-LPAH relation across cosmic time, 2) test the validity of the IR8=LIR/L8 and LPAH/LIR as tracers of star formation efficiency, as recently proposed by various studies and 3) investigate how the LCO/LPAH ratio varies as a function of dust temperature of the ISM.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysics Department, Instituto de Fisica de Cantabria CSIC/UC
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
